fields.description: There have been a number of security issues in non-atlassian software caused by using the HOST header of an incoming request. Therefore, this suggestion issue to request that when FECRU sees a request with a HOST header that does not match the instance's server url to redirect the request to the server url.
fields.summary: Redirect requests that have a different HOST header than what is configured to the correct (configured) server url.

fields.description:
*Problem:*

FishEye/Crucible fails to render list of users in case one user is defined in two user directories and has 'fisheye user' global permission set in one of them, while in another directory is marked as inactive and the second directory has higher priority.

 

*Steps to reproduce:*
 * create a user in 'Internal' directory
 * by default this user will be granted 'fisheye user' and 'crucible user' global permissions
 * create the same user in external directory (JIRA), uncheck the 'active' checkbox
 * configure user directories: JIRA directory as first, internal directory as second
 * click 'synchronise' link
 * the "Users" list on administration page (/admin/userAdmin.do) shows this user
 * note: user has an empty avatar (grey icon), clicking on the user loads a page with "IllegalStateException user does not exist" error
 * an attempt to delete a user shows "success", but the user is still shown on the list
 * the global user list (/users) fails with the "cannot get committers for a non-existent Fisheye user" error:
  

{noformat}
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: cannot get committers for a non-existent Fisheye user [jordi.nadal] at com.cenqua.fisheye.model.manager.CommitterUserMappingManagerImpl.getAllCommittersForUser(CommitterUserMappingManagerImpl.java:280) [fisheye.jar:?] ... at com.atlassian.fisheye.user.action.userlistgenerator.GlobalUserListGenerator.addCommitsToPeople(GlobalUserListGenerator.java:54) [fisheye.jar:?] at com.atlassian.fisheye.user.action.userlistgenerator.UserListGenerator.completeUserData(UserListGenerator.java:88) [fisheye.jar:?]
{noformat}

*Workaround:*
 * swap the order of user directories - i.e. to have the internal first, JIRA as second
 * delete the user - it will be removed from the internal directory (alternatively - remove it from 'fisheye-user' and 'crucible-users' groups to revoke user's global permissions)
 * switch the order of directories back
fields.summary: IllegalArgumentException cannot get committers for a non-existent Fisheye user

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
 The scenario is the following:
 * Two directories are present in Fisheye and they share at least one user
 * The user is inactive the first of the two directories and active in the other one
 * FishEye syncs the two directories and syncs the user being it active in one of the two directories
 * When the user name is clicked in the user list a check is performed in the directories to see if the user is present in them.
 The check is performed from the first directory until the last one and it stops when it succeeds or fails with an error.
 * The user directory with the inactive user is checked and it returns the following error:
 !Screen Shot 2016-12-16 at 14.42.12.png|thumbnail! 
 * The research for user details stops.


h3. Suggested Solution
* Make FishEye show a more graceful error
*OR*
* Do not show the user at all

h3. Why this is important
The error makes the admin think there is something wrong in the directory or in the configuration.
fields.summary: As an administrator I would like a better error management for inactive users in crowd directories

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When indexing a repository, the index hangs on a changeset. Through investigation, it is discovered that FishEye enters a never ending loop. This loop was happening in a part of code where we would traverse commit ancestors graph; In case the ancestor commit was the same as the child commit we would enter a never ending loop.
fields.summary: FishEye loops on changeset while transversing commit graph

fields.description:
Currently FishEye uses [Perforce branch mappings|https://www.perforce.com/perforce/r14.2/manuals/cmdref/p4_branches.html] to link changesets to a particular branch. FishEye stores branch mappings in a HashMap and links a file revision to first matching mapping. Because of that such approach can cause problems if branch mappings overlap with each other and Perforce users change branch mappings very often. 

Such situation can lead to inconsistencies in repository structure. In example:
* the same repository indexed on different machines can result in branch discrepancies
* single file revision may have wrong predecessors

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

Proposed solution:
As a system administrator or repository administrator, I want to disable branch mappings for a single Perforce repository. Currently, it is possible to disable branch mappings globally for the whole instance, via JVM System property {{fisheye.p4.disable.branchspecs=true}}
fields.summary: As an administrator/repository administrator I want to disable Perforce branch mappings for a specific repository

fields.description:
h2. Steps to reproduce

# Have Perforce with at least one branch and head, where at least one file was copied to a branch from head
# Go to copied file revision activity. You should see something similar to this
 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 
# Click on {{Diff Latest}} button

h2. Expected behaviour

File diff page should be rendered with a diff between {{branch-2/file.txt@4}} and {{main/file.txt@1}}.

h2. Actual behaviour

FishEye ignores logical paths when calculating ancestry and shows _Could not resolve revision_ banner.
fields.summary: FishEye ignores logical paths in Perforce when it comes to rendering diff for a file revision

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Using the greater/lesser symbols as part of the commit will mess with JIRA linker regex only from the "Commit Graph" tab as per the screenshot below:
* !screenshot1.png|thumbnail!  
* !screenshot2.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create Application Link between FishEye and JIRA and have at least commit with the commit message like {{<PROJ-1>}} for an existing project issue key in JIRA
# Create a Linker for JIRA in FishEye with the following configurations:
# {noformat}
Regular Expression: [a-zA-Z]{2,}-\d+
Href: http://<Base_URL>:8080/browse/${0}
{noformat}
# Open up Commit Graphs tab

h3. Expected Results
The list show appear as how the commit message. As from example: {{<PROJ-1>}} 

h3. Actual Results
Some gibberish random text appear before the {{PROJ-1>}} as per the screenshot above.

Note that it does not get affected in Activity Stream
fields.summary: Using the greater/lesser symbols as part of the commit will mess with JIRA linker regex

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When running the [*"Release Report"*|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.atlassian.fecru.plugins.fecru-revset-report-plugin/server/overview] with a user that does not have access to the repository and the "Grant read access to anonymous users" option is not enabled, a NotPermittedException error message is presented to the user.

This use case can happen when users share the URL of a report among themselves.

This has been tested against the add on version +0.15+.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Make sure that the preconditions are met:
## +userB+ does not have access to the repository
## the "Grant read access to anonymous users" option is not enabled
# +userA+ retrieves the URL of the "Release Report" and shares it with +userB+
# +userB+ opens the URL

Example of a valid URL:
{noformat}
http://fisheye/plugins/servlet/revset-report/repository1?r1=d7a10b49b030c386aba69902e99b4dc80a0bcc6d&r2=5e7cbc27ff1b77acb69f3588947e3dc5892cc17b
{noformat}


h3. Expected Results
The +userB+ is redirected to the login screen if he is not logged in.
A user friendly message is displayed if the user is not logged in.

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is shown in the user interface: 
{noformat}

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When running the *"Code Metrics Report"* with a user that does not have access to the repository and the "Grant read access to anonymous users" option is not enabled, a NotPermittedException error message is presented to the user.

This use case can happen when users share the URL of a report among themselves.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Make sure that the preconditions are met:
## +userB+ does not have access to the repository
## the "Grant read access to anonymous users" option is not enabled
# +userA+ retrieves the URL of the "Code Metrics Report" and shares it with +userB+
# +userB+ opens the URL

h3. Expected Results
The +userB+ is redirected to the login screen if he is not logged in.
A user friendly message is displayed if the user is not logged in.

h3. Actual Results
The below exception is shown in the user interface: 
{noformat}
Problem rendering report: class com.atlassian.crucible.spi.services.NotPermittedException: No permission to access repository '<repository_name>'
{noformat}

No errors or warnings are reported in the logs.

h3.Workaround
No workaround is available.

h3. Notes
A similar error has been raised against the "Release Report" here: FE-6732.
fields.summary: The Code Metrics Report returns a NotPermittedException for a not logged in user

Incorrect error handling with Perforce can lead to missing metadata for some file revisions

fields.description:
h2. Actual behaviour

Currently when any perforce related error happens when FishEye tries to get [p4 describe -dn|https://www.perforce.com/perforce/r15.2/manuals/cmdref/p4_describe.html] for a batch of changesets, it fallbacks and tries to get the data for changesets one-by-one.

If this fail, FishEye will try to call _p4 describe -s_ which lists only basic information about changeset and don't provide diff information which is required to calculate lines added and removed for a file revision in changeset.

 

This result in incorrect lines added/removed counters and potentially can lead to blame calculation errors further in the indexing process

!image-2016-12-01-09-01-35-031.png!

Correct changeset information:

!image-2016-12-01-09-02-09-804.png!
h2. Expected behaviour 

FishEye correctly handles errors which come from Perforce, correctly fallbacks from batch mode and propagates the exception if it can't get the required information from perforce.
fields.summary: Incorrect error handling with Perforce can lead to missing lines added/removed counters for a file revisions

fields.description:
h2. Actual behaviour

Currently when any perforce related error happens when FishEye tries to get [p4 describe -dn|https://www.perforce.com/perforce/r15.2/manuals/cmdref/p4_describe.html] for a batch of changesets, it fallbacks and tries to get the data for changesets one-by-one. If this fail, FishEye will try to call _p4 describe -s_ and if this will fail again FishEye will ignore given changeset as it wouldn't exist in a repository. This will lead to missing changesets information and FishEye repository model won't represent actual repository structure. 

FishEye will log the following message to log files:
{noformat}Removing changelist 321{noformat}
 

However, the bug can present itself long after the log file rotates and log message is already gone. This lead to hardly reproducible problems which are nightmare to find the root cause. Missing changeset information can have an impact on whole FishEye&Crucible products, e.g. file ancestries, commit graphs, diff generation.

 
h2. Expected behaviour 

FishEye correctly handles which come from Perforce, correctly fallbacks from batch mode and does not loose any changeset information. In case of persistent errors, propagate the exception into upper callee levels.
fields.summary: Incorrect error handling with Perforce can lead to missing changeset in FishEye repository data

Workaround  (HSQLDB):

Check for duplicates:
{noformat}
select cru_source_name, cru_path, TRIM(BOTH from cru_revision), count(*) 
from cru_revision 
group by cru_source_name, cru_path, TRIM(BOTH from cru_revision) 
having count(*) > 1
{noformat}

Find entries with trailing or leading spaces:
{noformat}
select cru_source_name, cru_path, cru_revision from cru_revision 
where TRIM(BOTH from cru_revision) != cru_revision
{noformat} 

and delete them.

fields.description:
h3. Symptoms
After canceling Log Analyzer and starting to analyze another file, the progress bar stays at 0 and does not progress. There does not seem to be any progress made on the new file. If you have canceled the Log Analyzer, you can go to System Setting > System Info and see the hercules thread is listed as still running.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Start Log Analyzer to run on your most recent application log file. This duplication works better if you choose a large file.
# Cancel scan.
# Note that the hercules thread is running and still running.
# Start a second scan of another file.
# UI will show 0 progress until the first scan finishes.

h3. Expected Results
Cancel would stop the job and allow you to run the new file right away.

h3. Actual Results
Thread keeps running and uses a full CPU until the job is finished then it runs the next job. This is aggravated by Support Tools v 3.9.12 automatically running the standard log file.
 
h3. Notes
This was tested and reproducible on FishEye 4.2.1 and FishEye 4.2.0 using v 3.8.1 and v 3.9.12 of the Support Tools Add-on.
Was not able to duplicate on JIRA 6.4.13 v3.9.12 or Bitbucket Server 4.9.1 v3.9.6 and v 3.9.12 of the Support Tools Add-on.

h3.Workaround
Wait for all the jobs to finish.
Restart FishEye.
fields.summary: hercules thread keeps running after canceling Log Analyzer in FishEye 4.2.1

fields.description:
Keyboard navigation is very important when you cannot see the screen well enough to use a mouse. It appears that when the tab key is pressed, there are things on the page that are not tab stops.

So, a user cannot get to them without magnifying the screen a lot to try and find what is needed visually so it can be clicked.

To be truly accessible, a user should be able to use the application with only a keyboard.

Also, there are several elements on the page that when tabbed to, have no associated text for a screen reader to announce, so a user doesn't know what they are or what they do. It isn’t very helpful when the screen reader says nothing or something generic like “link”.
fields.summary: As a user I require improvements for the visually impaired specifically including labels and tab stops to all fields

fields.summary: Indexing fails for a git commit with a long author name

fields.description:
h3. Summary
As per [Git Integration guide for Fisheye/Crucible|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Git]:
{quote}
When you add a Bitbucket Server repository to FishEye, a push to the repository will by default automatically trigger FishEye to run an incremental index. No further configuration is required – you don't have to configure polling for new commits, or set up dedicated FishEye web hooks in your Bitbucket Server instance.
{quote}
h3. Environment
Bitbucket Server 4.9.1
Applinks setup between Fisheye/Crucible using OAuth

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Step 1
Create OAuth between Fisheye/Crucible and Bitbucket Server 
# Step 2
Add a Bitbucket Server repository as per the above guide
# Step 3
Push to the Git repository and check that the commit appears in Bitbucket Server and Fisheye/Crucible UI

h3. Expected Results
Fisheye/Crucible triggers an incremental sync only when it detects a new commit in Bitbucket Server Git repository

h3. Actual Results
Fisheye/Crucible logs indicate that it is still using the configured/default polling interval to trigger the incremental index:
{noformat}
2016-10-26 09:51:27,716 DEBUG [IncrPing1 blah1 ] fisheye RepositoryStatus-setMessage - Status change [blah1]: Getting updates from ssh://git@localhost:7999/blah/blah1.git
.
.
2016-10-26 09:51:37,720 DEBUG [IncrPing1 blah1 ] fisheye RepositoryStatus-setMessage - Status change [blah1]: Getting updates from ssh://git@localhost:7999/blah/blah1.git
.
.
2016-10-26 09:51:47,721 DEBUG [IncrPing1 blah1 ] fisheye RepositoryStatus-setMessage - Status change [blah1]: Getting updates from ssh://git@localhost:7999/blah/blah1.git
{noformat}
The default polling interval is set to 10sec as indicated by the incremental thread running every 10sec.

h3.Workaround

None available yet.
fields.summary: Scheduled polling being used for configured Bitbucket Server repositories rather than commit hook

fields.description:
Currently LOC is calculated for each repository. 

If users want to calculate that information for all repositories they need to access each repository in order to retrieve their respective LOC.

FishEye should have a report in which LOC is calculated for all repositories at once.
fields.summary: Provide LOC report for all repositories at once

fields.description:
Search can be restricted by a specific branch: 

[Search query on branch|https://fisheye.dev.internal.atlassian.com/search/fecru-lfs/?comment=&contents=&addedText=&deletedText=&filename=src%2Fjava%2Fcom%2Fcenqua%2Ffisheye%2F**%2F*&branch=4.3-FECRU-6901-byteman-log-threaddumps&tag=&fromdate=&todate=&datesortorder=DESCENDING&groupby=file&col=path&col=revision&col=author&col=date&col=csid&col=totalLines&col=linesAdded&col=linesRemoved&refresh=y].

I can see all the revisions that happened on that branch:
 !image-2016-10-21-08-18-14-705.png|thumbnail! 

However, when I select "Search HEAD only", I get all the files, not only the ones that were modified on that branch:

[Search query on branch with HEAD=true|https://fisheye.dev.internal.atlassian.com/search/fecru-lfs/?head=true&comment=&contents=&addedText=&deletedText=&filename=src%2Fjava%2Fcom%2Fcenqua%2Ffisheye%2F**%2F*&branch=4.3-FECRU-6901-byteman-log-threaddumps&tag=&fromdate=&todate=&datesortorder=DESCENDING&groupby=file&col=path&col=revision&col=author&col=date&col=csid&col=totalLines&col=linesAdded&col=linesRemoved&refresh=y]

  !image-2016-10-21-08-17-27-029.png|thumbnail! 

This works as expected in SVN:

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

vs.

 !screenshot-2.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Advanced search with 'Search HEAD only' ignores branch parameter in git repositories

fields.description:
h3. Summary

A commit message containing a string _similar_ to a JIRA issue will incorrectly link to the issue. Specifically, a commit message that resembles a JIRA issue key with spaces in it.

h3. Environment

FishEye/Crucible 4.2.0


h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an application link between FishEye and JIRA
 # Create a project called *NS*
 # Create an issue
 # Commit a change in the repo using git commit -m "test commit *** XX ns - 1 ns ***"
 # In Jira development panel we will see the commit

h3. Expected Results

This commit shouldn't be visible in JIRA issue

h3. Summary

h3. Notes
* This happens when trying to update the add-on with the password-only admin, as FishEye relies on a real user, who's an administrator, to allow the update.

h3.Workaround
Create a real user and turn him administrator:
# Go to {{Administration > Users}} and create a new user.
# Go to {{Administration > Administrators}} and turn this user an admin.
# Log in as this user, then try to update the add-on again.
# The update still may fail with the error described at [https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-5629], for which you can follow the workaround suggested on that report.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently when indexing a partial repository (for example using a *Start Revision* for SVN) lines created in revisions prior to the first indexed commit are attributed to "No author". This causes the LOC reports and charts to be skewed when you are looking for metrics from the first indexed revision onward.
h3. Suggested Solution

Add a check box with the title "Exclude 'No Author'" which will filter out LOC attributed to "no Author". It would be a toggle so that the report builder would still be able to see the relative amounts of new commits versus those that came before the first indexed commit.
h3. Workaround #1

There is an easy workaround to filter out "No author" committer from LoC charts:

use Author(s) filter to select multiple committers excluding "No author"
See screenshot for details:

!screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!
h3. Workaround

Re-index the whole repository.
fields.summary: As a user I'd like to filter out "No author" from the LOC Charts

fields.description:

ExecutionException: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Host name may not contain blanks
{code}

h2. Workaround 
This issue might be avoided if properties pulled in from any properties files were trimmed of trailing whitespaces.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When a committer adds a branch to a Perforce repository, FishEye blames all of the LOC in the branch on the committer instead of the original authors 

h3. Steps to Reproduce.
# Create a Perforce repository.
# Commit some changes to a file from Author1.
# Commit some changes to the same file from Author2.
# Have Author2 create a new branch.
# View the repository Activity screen; you will see that the count for all changes from both Authors are attributed to Author2.
# View the Source screen for the file; all of the individual lines are attributed correctly. 

h3. Expected Results
The original authors will retain their LOC counts in the Activity screen.

h3. Actual Results
All LOC are attributed to the user who created the new branch.
Screenshots are attached.
fields.summary: LOC Count shows incorrect blame when adding a branch

h3.Workaround

fields.description:
h2. Observation
I was expecting to see the commits related with selected project when browsing project page https://fisheye.dev.internal.atlassian.com/project/CR-CIP but found irrelevant commits there:

 !Screen Shot 2016-09-16 at 11.37.00.png|thumbnail! 

Seems to be working fine for other projects, e.g. https://fisheye.dev.internal.atlassian.com/project/CR-CLOV

 !Screen Shot 2016-09-16 at 11.37.24.png|thumbnail! 

h2. Investigation
Seems like the problem is caused by project's default repository being disabled.  This problematic CR-CIP project seem to not have default repository set (project admin page https://fisheye.dev.internal.atlassian.com/admin/editProject.do?id=7 shows first available repository in default repository), FishEye content for this repository is empty as well https://fisheye.dev.internal.atlassian.com/admin/viewFisheyeProject.do?id=7.
But when I enable "clov-svn-old" repository (it was disabled before), apparently activity stream displays only its commits, as expected.   In project admin page I can see "clov-svn-old" repository as default one.

h2. Diagnosis
Seems like project activity page doesn't cope well with default project's repository being disabled.  Rather than falling down into showing activity of all FishEye repositories it should show no commits at all in such case.
Project admin page should indicate default project repository is disabled.

h2. note
Very likely the same would happen when default project's repository is deleted, to be verified.
fields.summary: Activity stream shows irrevelant commits when default project repository is disabled

fields.description:
*Problem*

Repository polling for instances with large number of repositories is inefficient and resource-hungry. Hence, we use [commit hooks|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Configuring+commit+hooks]. Currently in GitHub we have a service hooks. However,
{quote}
Services are pre-built integrations that perform certain actions when events occur on GitHub. They are not recommended for new projects and this functionality is scheduled to be removed from GitHub.
{quote}
GitHub team recommends that an integrated application for Fisheye is created instead. On their integrated applications directory there is HipChat and JIRA ([https://github.com/integrations]).

(!) Since January 31, 2019 GitHub stopped delivering services events (see https://developer.github.com/v3/guides/replacing-github-services)

*Workaround*

Use repository polling instead of services.

*Development notes*

* Fisheye shall accept POST in addition to PUT
* authentication (X-API-KEY header vs X-Hub-Signature) 

*References*

* https://developer.github.com/webhooks/#events
* https://developer.github.com/changes/2019-01-29-life-after-github-services/
fields.summary: Integrated Fisheye application for GitHub

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Connecting two FishEye/Crucible instances to the same database may lead to various problems:
- [Reviews mix file types, clear inconsistancies in stored diff cache|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHKB/Reviews+Mix+File+Types%2C+Clear+Inconsistancies+In+Stored+Diff+Cache]
- [Reviews cannot be created due to ConstraintViolationException|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHKB/Reviews+cannot+be+created+due+to+ConstraintViolationException]

h3. Suggested Solution
Implement a protection for these cases. Confluence for example provides a [Cluster Safety in a Single Node Standalone Instance|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFKB/Cluster+Safety+in+a+Single+Node+Standalone+Instance] which prevents a second instance to start up.
fields.summary: Prevent multiple Crucible instances connecting to a single database

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
As described on the [Perforce Jobs in FishEye and JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHKB/Perforce+Jobs+in+FishEye+and+JIRA] page, when committing a change fixing a Perforce Job, the JIRA issue key has to be provided in the commit message so that the commit is displayed in the JIRA development panel.

h3. Suggested Solution
Since FishEye is aware of the Perforce Job, which has already been linked to the JIRA issue, it would be desirable if the commit was available in the JIRA development panel without having to provide the JIRA issue key.


h3. Workaround
Add the Jira issue key to every commit message/changelist description in Perforce.
fields.summary: As a user, I want FishEye to link the Perforce commit with a linked Job to a JIRA issue, so that I don't have to provide the JIRA issue key on every commit

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If a user selects a JIRA issue launching into the modal window and chooses a workflow transition, custom field values are overwritten or defaulted if there is a transition screen provided.  Field value being overwritten occurs with an optional multi-select field. A default value being selected occurs with an optional single select field.

h3. Steps to Reproduce - 1
# Define a custom field (multi-select or single select) in JIRA, e.g. "Colors".
# Add this field to a project, e.g. "GUS"
# Create an issue in JIRA, e.g. "GUS-1" and assign a value, e.g. "Green", to this custom field.
# Make a commit and comment with the JIRA issue ID.
# In FishEye click on the JIRA issue ID from the recent activity.
# Transition the issue by clicking "Done".

h3. Expected Results - 1
The value visible in JIRA in the custom field, e.g. "Green", is also visible in the modal window.
 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Actual Results - 1
The custom field is visible without a value:
 !screenshot-2.png|thumbnail! 

If the issue is transitioned, the existing data "Green" in JIRA is removed or the value is overwritten.
fields.summary: Custom field values overwritten or set on modal transition

fields.description:
See [https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/40350709/answers/40351843]
 Basically FeCru REST (experimental as of 4.1) endpoints to remove global permissions:
 * DELETE /rest-service-fecru/admin/global-permissions/users/\{name}
 * DELETE /rest-service-fecru/admin/global-permissions/groups/\{name}

expect list of permission types to be deleted from a list. But ApplicationLinks API doesn't allow request body to be specified for DELETE requests, making it impossible to use this integration point.

Sending DELETE request with empty body ends up with 500 error and
 {{Uncaught exception thrown by REST service: No content to map to Object due to end of input}} error in the log.

We either need to change the API to not expect body in DELETE request (this doesn't seem forbidden by the HTTP spec though), improve ApplicationLinks API to allow body (it may take time for all the products to include this change) or simply allow empty body for those methods.

h3. Workaround

Use PUT allowLoggedIn:true and then PUT allowLoggedIn:false to reset all permitted groups, then perform a POST for each group permissions should be granted for, see https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/40350709/answers/40351843/comments/40353837
fields.summary: Can't remove global permissions via application links
Problem with finding text using cmd+f/ctrl+f in FishEye
FishEye/Crucible 4.0 or later run via AMS won't authenticate test users

fields.description:
FishEye 4.2.0 introduced the 'Display Name' attribute for a repository. It is being shown across the whole UI in FishEye/Crucible. It's also presented in a JIRA Development panel.

FishEye / Crucible gadgets, however use the "Repository" field, which requires the 'Name' ('Repository key'), instead of the 'Display Name'. It applies for both edit and view modes in gadgets. See screen shots.

 

An example for the 'FishEye Recent Changesets' gadget:


||edit mode||view mode||
|!fisheye_recent_changesets_edit.png|thumbnail!|!fisheye_recent_changesets_view.png|thumbnail!|

 

An example for the 'Changeset Review Coverage' gadget:

!changeset_review_coverage.png|thumbnail!

 

Affected gadgets:
 * FishEye Recent Changesets
 * FishEye Charts
 * Changeset Review Coverage
fields.summary: Use repository 'Display Name' instead of 'Name' ('Repository Key') in FishEye / Crucible gadgets

fields.description:
h1. Asynchronous global permission cache loading
h4. Loading cache in the background

In the default setup, the global permission cache is created synchronously. i.e. all web requests are blocked until cache is rebuilt. As this operation might take minutes, we came up with a mechanism that keeps using the old cache while the new one is being loaded in the background and replaces the old one only once the new one is ready.

First loading of the cache will still be blocking, because there's no old value to use.
h4. Disadvantages

Because the old cache is still used after an invalidation event has come, it means that changes to permission settings (FishEye/Crucible access, "can add repository" permission) are delayed. The greatest disadvantage is that users whose access has been revoked can still access FishEye until the cache is rebuilt.
h4. When to use

The asynchronous global permission cache loading should only be used when the application often becomes unresponsive due to long running global permission cache reloading.
h4. Enabling global permission cache reloading

Set [JVM system property|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/jvm-system-properties-298976942.html] to enable asynchronous global permission cache loading:
{noformat}
fisheye.use.async.global.permission.cache=true{noformat}

 
----
h1. Original ticket description
h3. Summary

When the instance has huge user base, ie. 100,000 users, FishEye is unresponsive due to Global Permissions cache recreation.
 This may take couple minutes to finish, while any http request is not able to load (As they have to wait for Global Permissions cache to be recreated).
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Connect FishEye to one or more directory with a significant number of users
 ## The synchronization of each directory will happen every hour
 ## After the synchronization of each directory, if there is at least one change, the Global Permissions cache will be recreated

h3. Expected Results

The recreation of the Global Permissions cache does not impact the FishEye performances and the user interface is always responsive.
h3. Actual Results

When checking the time required for the creation of the global permission cache, high values are reported.
 In the following example, the recreation of the cache took {{202192}} milliseconds (~ 3 minutes):
{noformat}
DEBUG [qtp787122337-77080 ] fisheye Timer-output - -> Loading global permission cache mem_usage = 2655336032 heapsize = 3533176832 freemem = 877840800
DEBUG [qtp787122337-77080 ] fisheye Timer-output - <- Loading global permission cache  time 202192 millis mem_usage = 2427321272 heapsize = 3300917248 freemem = 873595976
{noformat}
During this time all http requests will be be queued.
h3. Notes

The number of users can be checked via the repository by running the following query on FishEye 4.0+:
{noformat}
select directory_id, count(directory_id)
from cwd_user
group by directory_id
{noformat}
h2. Workaround

At the moment FishEye/Crucible will struggle to cope with such large user bases assuming all of them need access to FishEye/Crucible.  But if you don't expect all those users to use FishEye/Crucible and can narrow them down, consider following workaround:
 # create in remote directory group of set of groups that would together contain all the users expected to have access to FishEye/Crucible, if such group(s) don't exist yet
 # if remote directory can be configured to return only subset of users (e.g. Atlassian Crowd), configure it so FishEye/Crucible will synchronise only those groups
 # or configure appropriate filters in User Directories administration of FishEye/Crucible to synchronise only those groups
fields.summary: FishEye blocked when a large user base is configured in Global Permissions

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently we do not have a way to see the version of Crowd included in various products. This causes problems when troubleshooting User Directory or Account issues as we have no easy way of identifying if there is an existing Crowd bug which applies.
h3. Suggested Solution

Include Crowd version in the user interface and {{application.xml}} file. This could be in the "System Information" tab under Support Tools, Users, and/or User Directories screens.
h3. Workaround
{code:java}
find $FISHEYE_HOME -iname \*crowd\*.jar
{code}
or
 # Request access to the source code repository.
 # Clone the repository.
 # search the {{pom.xml}} files.
fields.summary: Include the version of Crowd in the UI and application.xml file

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Groups containing special characters (e.g. {{#}} or {{/}}) cannot be added as Reviewers.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a group with a special character in it in an external user directory (e.g. JIRA or LDAP)
# Synchronize the group to FishEye
# Add the groups as a reviewer to a review

h3. Expected Results
The users belonging to the group are added as reviewer.

h3. Actual Results
The users are not added as reviewer, and the following message is displayed in the user interface:
{noformat}
Failed to fetch group members. Check Internet connection or contact your administrator.
{noformat}

!AddAGroupWithSpecialCharacter.png|width=600px!
 
h3. Notes
Groups with special characters cannot be created directly in FishEye, they can only be imported by and external user directory.
When attempting to create a group with special characters in FishEye, the following message is shown:
{quote}
Group name can only contain alphanumeric, underscore, at ('@'), dot, dash or backslash
{quote}

A call for group with id {{////}} will result in following request call:
<FISHEYE_URL>/rest-service/reviewer-search/CR-3/groups///////members

A call for group with id starting with {{#}} will result in following request call:
<FISHEYE_URL>/fisheye/rest-service/reviewer-search/CR-27/groups/

The following is an expected request call:
<FISHEYE_URL>/fisheye/rest-service/reviewer-search/CR-27/groups/<group_name>/members

h3.Workaround
No workaround is currently available.
fields.summary: Adding a group as a reviewer fails when the group id contains special characters because is not encoded

fields.description: The suggestion is to add a suggestion to verify the browser's {{Developer Tools > Network tab}} during the troubleshooting of an Application Link issue, as it may help clarifying some issues which do not display in the application logs, such as requests being blocked, or mixed content not being loaded as described at [https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFKB/Tabs+are+not+loading+under+Application+Links+authentication+method].
fields.summary: Add suggestion for browser troubleshooting to the Application Link Troubleshooting Guide

fields.description:
This suggestion apply for the following documents:
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Using+Smart+Commits
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Processing+JIRA+Software+issues+with+Smart+Commit+messages
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Using+Smart+Commits+in+Bitbucket+Server

In the table under the *Workflow transitions* section, in the *Notes* line, include the following bullet point for a transition to be used in a smart commit:
bq. * The transition's name must contain only alpha and hyphen characters
fields.summary: Include note for transitions in the Using Smart Commits page
Support Java 11 in FishEye and Crucible

fields.description:
The list of users for a given repository shows 0 commits if the repository name in the browser URL is written in an incorrect case.

*How to reproduce:*
# Assuming there is a repository called "Svn" already indexed in FishEye
# Navigate to repository through repository list and go to "Users" tab (http://localhost:8060/users/Svn), and note that commit information shows correctly:
!Screen Shot 2016-08-15 at 4.33.07 PM.png|thumbnail!
# Modify the URL to http://localhost:8060/users/svn, (note that "svn" does not match repository name "Svn"), and observe 0 commits per user:
!Screen Shot 2016-08-15 at 4.34.52 PM.png|thumbnail!
# Keeping the repository name incorrect, navigate to its Activity tab (http://localhost:8060/changelog/svn) and observe correct data:
!Screen Shot 2016-08-15 at 4.35.05 PM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Repository name should not be case sensitive when navigating to its users list

fields.description:
h3. Summary
This is a follow up to FE-6201.

According to [this comment|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-6201?focusedCommentId=832030&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-832030], the smart commit transition command is supposed to only work with the user's preferred language. For example, if JIRA language is set to Chinese language, users will need to use transition name in Chinese language in order for the smart commit to work. However, this does not work.

It is likely that the regex to filter out the smart commit commands never worked for special characters in the first place, so any languages that use non-English characters will cause the smart commit to fail.

Basically, when JIRA is set to a language other than English and that language has special characters (such as Chinese), BOTH English/Chinese smart commit messages will not work.

h3. Environment
FishEye 3.9.0
JIRA 7.1.9

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an Application Links from JIRA to FishEye.
# Change to Chinese language via JIRA user profile/global configuration
# Create a new ticket from JIRA ie: TES-1
# Enable FishEye smart commits
# Add a commit message, ie: "TES-1 #完成 #COMMENT 026" (完成 = Done)
# The issue will not transition to 完成, but the comment will still be added to the ticket.

h3. Expected Results
Issue should transition to 完成 and comment is added.

h3. Actual Results
Issue does not transition to 完成, but the comment is added.
 
h3. Notes
https://stash.atlassian.com/login?next=/projects/FECRU/repos/fecru/browse/src/bundled-plugins/bundled/commithooks/fecru-jiracommithook-plugin/src/main/java/com/atlassian/fecru/plugin/commithook/jira/commands/CommitCommentParser.java

{code}public static final Pattern COMMAND_PATTERN = Pattern.compile("#([A-Za-z][A-Za-z\\-]*)");{code}

This looks like it will only work for English characters? Either fix the regex, or give users an option to use English in smart commits regardless of what their preferred language is in JIRA.

h3.Workaround
No workaround, unless JIRA admin manually removes the JIRA workflow transition translation from the language pack to allow users to commit in English.
fields.summary: FishEye smart commit does not work with Chinese transition name from JIRA workflow

fields.description:
Seems like Fecru data providers are not defined for every _web resource_ which uses them, thus some time the code may fail with JS undefined error
{noformat}
com.atlassian.plugins.atlassian-nps-plugin:nps-util.js:3 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'toLowerCase' of undefined
{noformat}
 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

h2. HTR
Make sure admin didn't ack on NPS data dialog.

# Start Fisheye&Crucible debug instance by  {{ant debug}}
# Enable analytics
# Refresh page, NPS initializer will catch analytics settings had changed
## NPS tries to initialize itself and shows _Acknowledge Dialog_ 
## It requires {{fecru.js}} which is required by all resources in the scope
## But FECRU data providers are not, thus {{Product.getProductName}} fails miserably
fields.summary: JS error when NPS plugin is being initialized after Analytics was enabled

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When amending a commit message in a repository (specifically SVN in this case) a call is not sent out to JIRA to notify of the change like when a Smart Commit is initially processed. After 30 minutes JIRA seems to reach out for FishEye for any updates and notices the change, then the commit message appears in the new JIRA ticket.
h3. Steps to reproduce
 # Create a Smart Commit referencing a JIRA ticket
 # Amend the Commit message to contain another JIRA ticket
 # Perform a rescan on the SVN repo in FishEye
 # Wait 30 minutes
fields.summary: Amended commits are not reflected in linked JIRA tickets until after 30 minutes

fields.description:
Profile settings / Favourites.
Apparently it is possible to click on the start and set a label on the favourite.
Setting "my secret name for favourite <script>alert('d');</script>" label executes the alert. Visiting favourites page later (or even opening Update favourite dialog) doesn't show alert anymore.
Seems like non-persisted XSS then, also I can't see any page to share favourites with other users, so the only potential victim of this XSS is the same user.
fields.summary: Setting label on the favourite item leads to its evaluation (XSS)

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When "Enable aliasing" is enabled in Crowd, the connection to Crowd from FishEye fails and users are not able to login.

This problem is caused by CWD-4308, which has been resolved in Crowd 2.8.4.

h3. Environment
* Crowd prior to 2.8.4

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Connect FishEye to Crowd
# "Enable aliasing" in the Crowd Options tab

h3. Expected Results
FishEye can successfully connect to Crowd.

h3. Actual Results
The following is shown in the FishEye user interface in the {{Configure Atlassian Crowd Server}}
{noformat}
Connection test failed. Response from the server:
Error from Crowd server propagated to here via REST API (check the Crowd server logs for details): The validated object is null
{noformat}

The below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-fisheye-YYYY-MM-DD.log}} file:
{noformat}

fields.summary: In changeset view show the commit date, rather than how long ago it has happened

fields.description:
"Search HEAD only" and "branch" options don't make much sense when searching by content in non-SVN repositories as only the newest revision content is kept in index (regardless of branch). 

Moreover if the newest revision is a deletion, path content is not searchable at all which is even more confusing.
fields.summary: Make it clear in FishEye advanced search UI that for non-SVN repositories only a content of the newest revision for a path gets indexed

fields.description: As per https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-7794 a new property is now available in Fisheye/Crucible ''fisheye.lucene.boolean.query.max.clause.count" which has not been documented under the [Fisheye JVM system properties|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/JVM+system+properties] guide on CAC.
fields.summary: Add the fisheye.lucene.boolean.query.max.clause.count property to CAC documentation

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When attempting to transition a JIRA issue from Fisheye, if there are 4 or more workflow transitions the More button shows up with an arrow dropdown. This button currently doesn't reveal anything.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have JIRA and Fisheye applinked together
# Link a code review to a JIRA Issue
# Ensure that the JIRA Issue has a workflow that has more than 4 workflow statuses it can be transitioned to
# From Fisheye, select the JIRA Issue


h3. Expected Results
When viewing the issue you should be able to select the More dropdown for additional transitions

h3. Actual Results
Selecting the More dropdown reveals nothing and has no action 

 
h3. Notes
This only occurs when 3 or more workflow transitions are available 

h3.Workaround
There is no workaround currently
fields.summary: Unable to select more dropdown when JIRA issue has more than 4 workflow transitions
Permission scheme action groups get lost during upgrade when groups are from external directory and contain upper case characters
Project default reviewers groups / allowed review participants groups get lost during upgrade when groups are from external directory and contain upper case characters

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When selecting a file in the Source view, the changesets chosen for the diff are based on the previous first revision instead of the latest.

h3. Steps to Reproduce.
# Add 2 files (A and B) to a repository indexed by FishEye.
# Update and re-commit to both files.
# Make additional changes to A and recommit.
# Make another change to A and recommit.
# Allow FishEye to index all of the commits (total 2 commits for B and 4 commits for A).
# Go to the Source view for B.
# Set the "From" commit of B to the first commit of this file.
# Leave the "To" commit at the second commit.
# Click on file A.

h3. Expected Results
* When clicking on A, the "To" commit is the latest commit for this file in the repository/branch
* The "From" commit is latest -1 commit for this file to show the last change to the file.

h3. Actual Results
* The "From" commit for A is either same commit as selected for B, or the "From" commit that last appeared for A if there is not matching commit to B.
* The "To" commit is the next commit for the file. 
 
h3.Workaround
Manually change the "To" and "From" commits for each file where the issue occurs.
fields.summary: Source view does not update the changeset diffs properly

fields.description:
After upgrading to 4.1.0 version of FishEye, some users may lose access to repositories they were able to access before.  This affects permissions granted to groups containing upper case characters in their names.

h2. Workaround 
Fixing is not possible through the UI because it won't allow to add permissions considered duplicate, lowercasing group names directly in database (in {{cru_repo_group_perm}} table) is required.
fields.summary: Repository permissions get lost during upgrade when groups contained upper case characters

fields.description:
Global permissions UI is broken when group contains upper case letters in name.  On page reload the page will show actual state, with no duplicates presented.  But if user attempts to add permissions for a group that contains upper case characters in its name and permissions for that group existed already, the UI will show this group twice - once with lowercase spelling and once with original case spelling.  Duplicated entry disappears on page reload.

The issue most probably lies in {{GlobalPermissionsResource#groupsWithoutAnyPermissions}}. 

 !image-2016-06-22-10-57-43-805.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Global permissions UI may show duplicate groups when they contain upper case characters

fields.description:
The sample repository have 1000 branches with the pattern:
{noformat}
git checkout -b branch-$i-test-xx$i
{noformat}

However, upon typing {{branch}}, it only list the last created branch (in this case)
!screenshot.png|thumbnail! 

As for the current workaround, typing the entire branch name exactly in one go, will still filter a list changesets of that particular branch.
fields.summary: Typing partial string on a branch name while adding content via "Browse changeset" will not list branches

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The Commit History in FishEye shows a broken image.

h3. Environment
FishEye 4.0+

h3. Steps to Reproduce
NA

h3. Expected Results
The chart is correctly generated and displayed.

h3. Actual Results
The chart is not displayed. When trying to access the chart to open it in a separate tab, the below exception is thrown in the {{atlassian-fisheye-YYYY-MM-DD.log}} file:
{noformat}
fisheye TotalityFilter-logExceptionDetails - Exception "java.lang.NullPointerException" (javax.servlet.ServletException) while processing "/fe/commitSparkline.do" (Referer:"<repository_url>")
javax.servlet.ServletException: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.opensymphony.webwork.dispatcher.DispatcherUtils.serviceAction(DispatcherUtils.java:285) [webwork-2.2.7-atlassian-29.jar:?]
	at com.opensymphony.webwork.dispatcher.ServletDispatcher.service(ServletDispatcher.java:111) [webwork-2.2.7-atlassian-29.jar:?]
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
Add an "Author mapping" so that the user will be mapped to the repository, this will allow the chart to be properly created.
fields.summary: Commit History chart displays a broken image
